title: MPs demand to know why Facebook has decided to exempt political statements from fact-checking
text:
MPs have demanded Facebook explain why political adverts will be exempt from a new fact-checking system - a move which opens the door to politicians and parties lying to the electorate via the social media platform.

Nick Clegg, former deputy Prime Minister and now Facebook's vice-president for global affairs and communications, has received a letter from MPs demanding answers, calling the change 'particularly concerning'.

Damian Collins, the chair of the House of Commons' digital, culture, media and sport select committee, sent Mr Clegg three questions about the rule change, which the company announced on Monday.

Writing in the Telegraph on Monday, Facebook's Vice President of Policy Solutions Richard Allam said the company had beefed up its defences ahead of a coming general election, deleting fake accounts and making political advertisers confirm their ID and status as UK citizens,

Former Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg, now Facebook's vice-president for global affairs and communications, in London this summer

'But,' he went on, 'while we are taking a number of steps, there are many areas where it's simply not appropriate for a private company like Facebook to be setting the rules of the game or calling the shots.

'For instance, we do not believe it should be our role to fact check or judge the veracity of what politicians say – not least since political speech is heavily scrutinised by the media and our democratic processes.'

Mr Collins has now asked Mr Clegg: ''Why was the decision taken to change Facebook's policy, given the heavy constraint this will place on Facebook's ability to combat online disinformation in the run-up to elections around the world, and a possible UK general election in particular?'

Collins also queried the role of the Facebook team which monitors 'elections integrity' in the decision-making process.

Facebook employee Yaël Eisenstat said on Twitter she had previously suggested scanning ads for misinformation to 'silent' responses from her bosses.

The global social media giant says it is deferring to national Parliament on the matter of political speech and scrutiny

Damian Collins MP is chair of the House of Commons' digital, culture, media and sport select committee

So Mr Collins asked: 'What proposals has [the team] made, to what extent were these proposals determined to be feasible, and on what grounds were they not progressed?'

He also asked about whether Facebook would be formalising its relationship with its third-party fact checkers 'in the long-term'.

Mr Allam on Monday said the company would be teaming up with independent fact checkeing organisations - including, in the UK, fact-checking charity Full Fact, - to 'to combat the spread of misinformation and viral hoaxes'.

'Images and videos on Facebook which they assess to be untrue will now be more clearly labelled as false and we’ll continue pointing people to reports which debunk the myth', he said.

However the fact checking teams are likely to be overwhelmed by the sheer amount of content uploaded to facebook.

Collins's letter comes on the heels of a major series of announcements by Facebook designed to plan for a US election in 2020, including stricter rules on disclosing who controls a popular page, tighter regulations on hate speech, and new bans on political adverts that attack democracy in general.
description: Damian Collins, chair of the House of Commons culture committee, has written to Nick Clegg at Facebook to ask about the recent rule change allowing politicians to lie in adverts.
